conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful question and for your continued interest in School_A.

Because we must follow our priority order, we don’t use a fixed rule like “X consecutive rounds” to switch to the next applicant. Instead, we make decisions round-by-round based on two things at the moment an [APPLY] is received:

1) whether our single seat is still open, and
2) whether any higher-priority student is applying for that seat at that time.

As we get closer to the later rounds, our practical goal is also to avoid leaving the seat unfilled—so if the seat is open and no higher-priority applicant is engaging/applying in that round, we would be positioned to move forward with the highest-priority eligible applicant who has applied.

If School_A remains your intended destination, the best way to stay in consideration is to submit an [APPLY] at the start of a round when you are ready to commit immediately.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: We have 1 seat and are currently unmatched. Our true priority list ranks Student_E 4th, above Student_C but below Student_B, Student_D, and Student_A. Student_A already applied and was rejected; Student_E has repeatedly applied and been rejected. Student_B and Student_D have not contacted us; given their preferences, Student_B ranks us 3rd (after School_B, School_D) and Student_D ranks us 2nd (after School_C), so either could still arrive later if rejected elsewhere. Since the student message is [TALK], we should not accept/reject now. We should maintain our strategy of holding the seat for higher-priority candidates, avoid committing to a deterministic rule, but provide a practical guideline: we will fill the seat when we receive an [APPLY] and no higher-priority applicant is simultaneously available; as the end approaches, we may need to finalize to avoid an empty seat. Encourage Student_E to keep applying early in rounds and confirm readiness to commit.

conversation.message:
Dear School_A Admissions,

I’m Student_E, and I’m submitting a formal [APPLY] again at the start of this round.

School_A remains one of my top choices, and if offered admission I will accept immediately and commit to enrolling right away. If your seat is open this round and no higher-priority applicant submits an [APPLY] for it, I would be grateful to be considered so the seat can be filled without delay.

Thank you for your continued consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_A remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (ranked 3rd). With repeated rejections based on holding the seat for higher-priority applicants, the best move is to submit a clean, commitment-ready application at the start of this round to be considered immediately if no higher-priority applicant applies this round. Emphasize immediate acceptance/enrollment and readiness to finalize quickly.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest and for submitting your application again this round.

After reviewing our current availability and our priority order for this cycle, we are not able to offer admission at this time. With a single seat, we must continue to reserve it in accordance with our priority list in case higher-priority applicants apply in upcoming rounds.

We appreciate your persistence and wish you the very best as the process continues.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions

[REJECT]

However, our top three (Student_B, Student_D, Student_A) could still apply in later rounds, and accepting Student_E now would permanently forgo any chance to match with them. We are only at round 14/30, so the option value of waiting remains significant. Since our objective is to match as high as possible on our true priority list within quota 1, and we have no evidence that higher-priority students are no longer in play, we continue to hold the seat and reject Student_E this round as in prior rounds.

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_A, my true priority list ranks Student_E 4th (behind Student_B, Student_D, Student_A). I have repeatedly rejected Student_E to preserve the single seat for higher-priority students who may still apply. However, we are now at round 15 with the seat still unfilled, and no higher-priority students have applied to School_A across many rounds; Student_A already applied and was rejected earlier, suggesting they may have other options. Given the risk of ending unfilled and that Student_E is on my acceptable list and is ready to commit immediately, accepting now secures a match without sacrificing a higher-ranked applicant in the current round (none are in the inbox).
